feed.title: Jeremy Davis - Sitecore, C# and web development
feed.subtitle: Sitecore, C# and web development

entry.title: Azure deploy issues
entry.content: Some of the most frustrating issues in IT happen when a thing which was working fine stops, and you're sure you didn't change anything. Now that very few people host their own infrastructure, these issues can be compounded because change or problems might happen in the internals of a system you have no control over. I got bitten by this recently, and while I have no answers I suspect this is worth writing up just because it may help other people who suffer similar challenges in the future.

entry.title: Driving browsers: #3 The states
entry.content: Time for the final part of my series on controlling a web browser. With code to load a browser, and the overarching State Machine to control it, this part finishes off with the code for some states to load a page and extract its markup. Plus a few conclusions...
entry.summary: Time for the final part of my series on controlling a web browser. With code to load a browser, and the overarching State Machine to control it, this part finishes off with the code for some states to load a page and extract its markup. Plus a few conclusions...

entry.title: Driving browsers: #2 The state machine
entry.content: Continuing from my previous post about firing up a browser in order to automate it, this post moves on to the overall pattern for how the browser can be controlled.
entry.summary: Continuing from my previous post about firing up a browser in order to automate it, this post moves on to the overall pattern for how the browser can be controlled.

entry.title: Driving browsers: #1 The Browser
entry.content: I bumped into an issue recently where I needed to write some code to scrape a bit of HTML. The usual .Net approach of using an HttpClient didn't work here - the web site in question made use of some "bot detection" code which relied on requests running JavaScript to validate them. So I needed a different approach to fetch the correct HTML. A while back I'd written some code to grab images of rendered HTML using the Chromium DevTools APIs, and I figured I could play a similar game here...
entry.summary: I bumped into an issue recently where I needed to write some code to scrape a bit of HTML. The usual .Net approach of using an HttpClient didn't work here - the web site in question made use of some "bot detection" code which relied on requests running JavaScript to validate them. So I needed a different approach to fetch the correct HTML. A while back I'd written some code to grab images of rendered HTML using the Chromium DevTools APIs, and I figured I could play a similar game here...

entry.title: Looking back on 300 posts
entry.content: When I started this blog nearly a decade ago, it was with the goal to see if I could motivate myself to write something about technical stuff on a regular basis. I certainly did not expect that I'd still be doing it 300 posts later. So in honour of that milestone I thought I'd look back at what's gone well here, a bit of what hasn't and how the technical world I'm writing for has changed since then...
